maml:description.maml:para: Used to show help about this 3CX XAPI Module.

3CX XAPI Module for managing PBX data. These scripts connect to the 3CX API (XAPI) to fetch and handle data. They use authentication credentials (XAPI Client ID and key/secret) to retrieve data from a specified PBX server (URL). The results are returned in JSON format and displayed in a structured manner, and export it to CSV/XLSX if necessary.
NOTES: - This script requires PowerShell 5.1 or 7.5+. Other versions are not supported. - Requires `.psm1` modules for common functions. - Parameters '-user', '-key' and '-url' are required, please replace their values with valid API user, key/secret, and 3CX URL. - The '-top' parameter limits the number of records fetched. - The '-skip' parameter allows skipping records for pagination. - When supported by endpoint date range will include both the starting and the ending date (-from and -to values).
Excel export notes: - Most scripts include export of data to Excel XLSX file format. - "ImportExcel" module is required for XLSX export and can be found here: https://github.com/dfinke/ImportExcel - Ensure that the ImportExcel module is installed and imported in your PowerShell session. You can install it using the following command: Install-Module -Name ImportExcel -Scope CurrentUser - After installing, import the module: Import-Module ImportExcel - In case that ImportExcel module is not available, XLSX export will be skipped, while CSV export remains as alternative format.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Show module help.
Equivalent to Get-3CXHelp command.
Getting detailed view of help file for Get-ActiveCalls command.

maml:description.maml:para: Used to access ActiveCalls from the 3CX XAPI endpoint.

This function connects to the 3CX XAPI and retrieves a list of currently active calls.
It requires authentication credentials and PBX URL. The results are returned in JSON format and displayed in a structured manner.
Provide API user/client ID used for authentication.
Provide API key (Client secret) used for authentication.
Provide full 3CX PBX URL, including protocol and port, such as https://YourSubdomainHere.3cx.eu:5001
Provide a number of records to skip for pagination.
Provide a number of records to fetch. NOTE: Parameter '-top' should not exceed 100 on this endpoint.
Provide API user/client ID used for authentication.
Provide API key (Client secret) used for authentication.
Provide full 3CX PBX URL, including protocol and port, such as https://YourSubdomainHere.3cx.eu:5001
Provide a number of records to skip for pagination.
Provide a number of records to fetch. NOTE: Parameter '-top' should not exceed 100 for some reason.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Getting first 100 records.
Skipping 150 records, then getting next 50 records.
Getting first 20 records.

maml:description.maml:para: Used to access ReportAbandonedQueueCalls from the 3CX XAPI endpoint.

It requires authentication credentials and PBX URL. The results are returned in JSON format and displayed in a structured manner.

maml:description.maml:para: Used to obtain access token from 3CX XAPI using API Client ID and secret.

Used to obtain access token from 3CX XAPI using API Client ID and secret.
Token is valid for 60 minutes, and can then be used with Invoke-XAPIRequestWithProgress to get data.
Provide API user/client ID used for authentication.
Provide API key (Client secret) used for authentication.
Provide full 3CX PBX URL, including protocol and port, such as https://YourSubdomainHere.3cx.eu:5001
Provide API user/client ID used for authentication.
Provide API key (Client secret) used for authentication.
Provide full 3CX PBX URL, including protocol and port, such as https://YourSubdomainHere.3cx.eu:5001

dev:remarks.maml:para: Obtain access token with Client ID "admin" and key from some3cxpbx.3cx.eu, will output to screen.
Obtain access token with Client ID "testuser" and key from yourpbx.3cx.eu, then store it to variable $mynewtoken to use later.

maml:description.maml:para: Used to obtain data from 3CX XAPI using access token.

Used to obtain data from 3CX XAPI using access token. Token can be obtained by Get-XAPIToken.
Calling this command manually will require you to handle data processing yourself. Original data returned from XAPI will be retained in global variable $global:3cxdata allowing you to further process it yourself.
To access data you can try some of these commands: - To see the context: $global:3cxdata.'@odata.context' - To see the count (if using $count=true in your query): $global:3cxdata.'@odata.count' - To see data itself: $global:3cxdata.value - To use the data directly you can maybe do something as simple as: - "Person/extension $($global:3cxdata.value.Caller) is currently calling person/extension $($global:3cxdata.value.Callee)"
Provide API access token as string, you can obtain it by running Get-XAPIToken.

Provide full endpoint URI such as https://YourSubdomainHere.3cx.eu:5001/xapi/v1/ActiveCalls?$count=true&$orderby=EstablishedAt asc&$skip=0&$top=100
NOTE: - Make sure to properly quote and/or escape special characters such as "$", see example for properly escaped URI sample string.
Used for approximation of HTTP request progress, if left undefined will default to 180s (3 minutes).
Enter message to be displayed in progress-bar while fetching data.

Accepts only 5 or 7, other values will produce error and stop execution. - pscheck 5 : denotes execution path used by PowerShell v5.1 that uses Invoke-RestMethod. - pscheck 7 : denotes execution path used by PowerShell v7.5.0 (or newer) that uses Invoke-WebRequest + ConvertFrom-Json -DateKind String - Versions between 6 and 7.4.x should use pscheck 5 as they don't know DateKind parameter - Note that returned date/time strings (originally in ISO 8601 format) may be auto-fromatted to local date/time of your PC - Officially I will not be supporting versions other than v5.1 and v7.5.0 (and newer, tested with 7.6.0 preview)
Provide API access token as string, you can obtain it by running Get-XAPIToken.

Provide full endpoint URI such as https://YourSubdomainHere.3cx.eu:5001/xapi/v1/ActiveCalls?$count=true&$orderby=EstablishedAt asc&$skip=0&$top=100
NOTE: - Make sure to properly quote and/or escape special characters such as "$", see example for properly escaped URI sample string.
Enter message to be displayed in progress-bar while fetching data.
Used for approximation of HTTP request progress, if left undefined will default to 180s (3 minutes).

Accepts only 5 or 7, other values will produce error and stop execution. - pscheck 5 : denotes execution path used by PowerShell v5.1 that uses Invoke-RestMethod. - pscheck 7 : denotes execution path used by PowerShell v7.5.0 (or newer) that uses Invoke-WebRequest + ConvertFrom-Json -DateKind String - Versions between 6 and 7.4.x should use pscheck 5 as they don't know DateKind parameter - Note that returned date/time strings (originally in ISO 8601 format) may be auto-fromatted to local date/time of your PC - Officially I will not be supporting versions other than v5.1 and v7.5.0 (and newer, tested with 7.6.0 preview)

dev:remarks.maml:para:
To get documentation file (swagger.yaml) from your XAPI you can use access token with URI. Swagger file contains list of endpoints and data types required and returned for easier understanding of XAPI.
NOTE: - Please use pscheck 5 to circumvent JSON conversion forced by pscheck 7, as returned data is YAML and not JSON.

After pinpointing endpoint name and structure in swagger file, you can proceed to access it, using your access token and URI.
NOTES: - Make sure to properly quote and/or escape special characters such as "$" otherwise you will get errors 404 / 500. - If you are using PowerShell 5.1 use pscheck 5, on PowerShell Core 7.5.0 or newer use pscheck 7 to keep ISO date/time format intact. Keep in mind other versions aren't properly supported. - Using pscheck 5 on older PS6/7 will work, it will just automatically convert date/time to local format used by your PC, you need to handle it yourself.
